    <title>Howler monkeys drop dead from the trees as heatwave rages in Mexico | World News | Sky News</title>
    <meta name="description" content="At least 83 have been found dead in the Gulf coast state of Tabasco">
    <link rel="canonical" href="https://news.sky.com/story/howler-monkeys-drop-dead-from-the-trees-as-heatwave-rages-in-mexico-13141048"/>
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width,minimum-scale=1,initial-scale=1">
    <link rel="shortcut icon" href="/resources/favicon.ico">
    <meta name="referrer" content="no-referrer-when-downgrade">


        <script type="application/ld+json">
          {"@context": "http://schema.org","@type": "NewsArticle","alternativeHeadline": "Dozens of howler monkeys drop dead from the trees as heatwave rages in Mexico","articleBody": "Mexico is so hot that howler monkeys have been dropping dead out of the trees. At least 83 of the primates, who are known for their roaring calls, were found dead in the Gulf coast state of Tabasco where temperatures are forecast to surpass 45C this week. Others were rescued by residents, including five that were rushed to a local vet who battled to save them. \"They arrived in critical condition, with dehydration and fever,\" said Dr Sergio Valenzuela. \"They were as limp as rags. It was heatstroke.\" A nationwide drought and heat waves have sent temperatures soaring across much of the country. In a statement over the weekend, Tabasco's Civil Protection agency attributed the deaths to dehydration. A source from the agency said that monkeys have been confirmed dead in three municipalities of the state.  In a forest outside Camalcalco, Tabasco, volunteers collected the corpses of mantled howler monkeys that died from high temperatures, before placing buckets of water and fruit to try to stave off more deaths. The mantled howler monkey is classified as vulnerable on the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) Red List. \"It is because the heat is so strong. I've been visiting the states for a long time and I have never felt it as much as now,\" Mexican President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador, who is from Tabasco, said on Monday when asked about the primate deaths. \"So, yes, we have to care for the animals and yes we are going to do it,\" he said in his regular news conference.  Later on Monday, Mexico's environment ministry said in a statement that it was coordinating efforts to address the monkeys' deaths, which it attributed to several possible reasons, including \"heat stroke, dehydration, malnutrition or the spraying of crops with toxic agrochemicals.\" Read more:Fire-breather fights off marauding mariachis in 'turf war'Images show damage inside plane after one killedTurbulence is getting worse - here's the main reason why Mexico's health ministry reported a preliminary count of 26 people who have died from heat-related causes between the start of Mexico's heat season on 17 March and 11 May. By 9 May at least nine cities in Mexico had set temperature records, with Ciudad Victoria, in the border state of Tamaulipas, clocking a broiling 47C. With sub-average rainfall across almost the entire country so far this year, lakes and reservoirs are drying up, water supplies are running out and authorities have had to truck in water for everything from hospitals to fire-fighting teams.  Low water levels at hydroelectric plants have contributed to power blackouts in some parts of the country. Wildlife biologist Gilberto Pozo counted about 83 of the animals dead or dying on the ground under trees. \"This is a sentinel species,\" Mr Pozo said, referring to the canary-in-a-coal mine effect where one species can say a lot about an ecosystem. \"It is telling us something about what is happening with climate change.\"","mainEntityOfPage": {"@type": "WebPage","url": "/story/howler-monkeys-drop-dead-from-the-trees-as-heatwave-rages-in-mexico-13141048"},"wordCount": "482","inLanguage": "en-GB","genre": "world","publisher": {"@type": "Organization","@id": "#Publisher","name": "Sky","logo": {"@type": "ImageObject","@id": "#Logo","url": "https://news.sky.com/assets/sky-news-logo.svg?v&#x3D;1","width": "255","height": "60"}},"headline": "Howler monkeys drop dead from the trees as heatwave rages in Mexico","description": "","dateline": "London, UK","copyrightHolder": {"@id":"#Publisher"},"author": {"@id":"#Publisher"},"datePublished": "2024-05-22T00:48:00Z","dateModified": "2024-05-22T02:22:00Z","dateCreated": "2024-05-22T00:50:00Z","image": {"@type": "ImageObject","url": "https://e3.365dm.com/24/05/2048x1152/skynews-monkey-mexico_6562283.jpg","width": 2048,"height": 1152 } ,"url":"/story/howler-monkeys-drop-dead-from-the-trees-as-heatwave-rages-in-mexico-13141048"  }
        </script>

As the UK's first dedicated 24-hour news channel, Sky News has built a deserved reputation for being the first to break major news as well as offering insight and analysis on the latest stories. It is renowned for the speed of its coverage and flexibility of reporting news live across all its platforms - TV, mobile, online, social, connected TV and radio.","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https:\/\/news.sky.com\/assets\/sky-news-logo.svg?v=1","width":136,"height":32},"foundingDate":1989,"founders":{"@type":"Person","name":"Rupert Murdoch"},"address":{"@type":"PostalAddress","streetAddress":"Grant Way","addressLocality":"Isleworth","addressRegion":"Greater London","postalCode":"TW7 5QD","addressCountry":"United Kingdom"},"contactPoint":{"@type":"ContactPoint","contactType":"customer support","telephone":"[(+44) 0333 7591 018]","email":"news@sky.com"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/skynews","https:\/\/twitter.com\/skynews","https:\/\/www.instagram.com\/skynews","https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/skynews","https:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Sky_News","https:\/\/plus.google.com\/+SkyNews"]}

Dozens of howler monkeys were found dead in the Gulf coast state while others were rescued by residents who rushed them to a local veterinarian. (AP Photo/Luis Sanchez)">

a[href]{color:var(--link-color)}.sdc-article-strapline__button[class]{color:var(--brand-1)}.sdc-article-strapline__button[class]:hover{background-color:var(--brand-1);border-color:var(--brand-1)}.sdc-article-widget-placeholder__button[class]{-webkit-appearance:none;-moz-appearance:none;appearance:none;background:none;border:1px solid;border-radius:3px;color:var(--link-color);cursor:pointer;display:inline-block;font-family:inherit;font-weight:400;line-height:1;padding:.64em 1em;vertical-align:middle}.sdc-article-widget-placeholder__button[class]:hover{background-color:var(--link-color);border-color:var(--link-color);color:#fff;text-decoration:none}.sdc-site-footer[class]{margin-top:var(--component-margin)}.sdc-site-header,.sdc-site-outbrain,.sdc-site-share--amp[class]{margin-bottom:var(--component-margin)}.sdc-site-share--amp[class]{padding-bottom:1em}.sdc-site-share--amp[class]>[class]{margin-right:.5em}:root{--article-body-width-max:1024px;--article-body-width-s:390px;--article-body-width-m:540px;--article-body-width-l:700px}.sdc-article-body{--link-decoration:underline;--link-decoration-hover:none;--article-link-colour:var(--link-color);--primary-text-colour:var(--text-color);--secondary-text-colour:var(--text-color-secondary);--heading-colour:var(--text-color);--text-selection-colour:var(--link-color);--default-border-color:var(--border-color);--article-base-font-size:16px;--body-font-size-default:var(--universal-body-font-size,1rem);--body-font-size-medium:var(--universal-body-font-size,1.22222rem);--h1-font-size-default:var(--universal-h1-font-size,2rem);--h1-font-size-medium:var(--universal-h1-font-size,2.66667rem);--h2-font-size-default:var(--universal-h2-font-size,1.77778rem);--h2-font-size-medium:var(--universal-h2-font-size,2rem);--h3-font-size-default:var(--universal-h3-font-size,1.55556rem);--h3-font-size-medium:var(--universal-h3-font-size,1.77778rem);--h4-font-size-default:var(--universal-h4-font-size,1.33333rem);--h4-font-size-medium:var(--universal-h4-font-size,1.44444rem);--h5-font-size-default:var(--universal-h5-font-size,1.11111rem);--h5-font-size-medium:var(--universal-h5-font-size,1.22222rem)}.sdc-article-body <div class="amp-page-limit">
    <main>
        
        <div class="sdc-article-header sdc-article-header--amp" data-component-name="sdc-article-header">
        
            <div class="sdc-article-header__titles">
        
                <h1 class="sdc-article-header__title" data-short-title="Howler monkeys drop dead from the trees as heatwave rages in Mexico"><span class="sdc-article-header__long-title">Howler monkeys drop dead from the trees as heatwave rages in Mexico</span></h1>
        
                    <h2 class="sdc-article-header__sub-title">At least 83 have been found dead in the Gulf coast state of Tabasco</h2>
            </div>
        
            <div class="sdc-article-header__details">
                
        
                    <p class="sdc-article-header__date-time">
                        <span class="clock"></span>
                        <time class="sdc-article-header__timestamp">
                            Wednesday 22 May 2024 03:22, UK
                        </time>
                    </p>
            </div>
        </div>
    

        

                    <div class="sdc-article-image sdc-article-image--amp sdc-article-widget">
                <figure class="sdc-article-image__figure">
                    <span class="sdc-article-image__wrapper" data-aspect-ratio="16/9">
                                <amp-img src="https://e3.365dm.com/24/05/768x432/skynews-monkey-mexico_6562283.jpg?20240522023525" width="768" height="432" layout="responsive" srcset="https://e3.365dm.com/24/05/384x216/skynews-monkey-mexico_6562283.jpg?20240522023525 380w, https://e3.365dm.com/24/05/768x432/skynews-monkey-mexico_6562283.jpg?20240522023525 760w" alt="A howler monkey sits inside a cage with others at a veterinarian clinic after they were rescued amid extremely high temperatures in Tecolutilla, Tabasco state, Mexico, Tuesday, May 21, 2024. Dozens of howler monkeys were found dead in the Gulf coast state while others were rescued by residents who rushed them to a local veterinarian. (AP Photo/Luis Sanchez)"></amp-img>
                    </span>
        
                        <figcaption class="ui-media-caption">
                            <span class="u-hide-visually">Image:</span>
                            <span class="ui-media-caption__caption-text">A howler monkey sits inside a cage with others at a veterinarian clinic. Pic: AP</span>
                        </figcaption>
                </figure>
            </div>
        
        
        
        
        
        
        

        <div class="sdc-site-share sdc-site-share--amp">
                <amp-social-share type="facebook" width="32" height="32" data-param-app_id="744976955573926" aria-label="Share on Facebook"></amp-social-share>
            <amp-social-share type="twitter" width="32" height="32" aria-label="Share on X"></amp-social-share>
            <amp-social-share type="whatsapp" width="32" height="32" aria-label="Share on WhatsApp"></amp-social-share>
            <amp-social-share type="email" width="32" height="32" aria-label="Share by email"></amp-social-share>
        </div>
       
        <div class="sdc-article-body sdc-article-body--lead sdc-article-body--amp">
                <p>Mexico is so hot that howler monkeys have been dropping dead out of the trees.</p>
            <p>At least 83 of the primates, who are known for their roaring calls, were found dead in the Gulf coast state of Tabasco where temperatures are forecast to surpass 45C this week.</p><p>Others were rescued by residents, including five that were rushed to a local vet who battled to save them.</p><p>"They arrived in critical condition, with dehydration and fever," said Dr Sergio Valenzuela.</p><p>"They were as limp as rags. It was heatstroke."</p>    <div class="sdc-article-image sdc-article-image--amp sdc-article-widget">
        <figure class="sdc-article-image__figure">
            <span class="sdc-article-image__wrapper" data-aspect-ratio="16/9">
                        <amp-img src="https://e3.365dm.com/24/05/768x432/skynews-monkey-mexico_6562287.jpg?20240522023736" width="768" height="432" layout="responsive" srcset="https://e3.365dm.com/24/05/384x216/skynews-monkey-mexico_6562287.jpg?20240522023736 380w, https://e3.365dm.com/24/05/768x432/skynews-monkey-mexico_6562287.jpg?20240522023736 760w" alt="A soldier removes the body of a howler monkey that died amid extremely high temperatures in Tecolutilla, Tabasco state, Mexico, May 21, 2024. Dozens of howler monkeys were found dead in the Gulf Coast state while others were rescued by residents who rushed them to a local veterinarian. (AP Photo/Luis Sanchez)"></amp-img>
            </span>

                <figcaption class="ui-media-caption">
                    <span class="u-hide-visually">Image:</span>
                    <span class="ui-media-caption__caption-text">A soldier removes the body of a howler monkey. Pic: AP</span>
                </figcaption>
        </figure>
    </div>
<p>A nationwide drought and heat waves have sent temperatures soaring across much of the country.</p><p>In a statement over the weekend, Tabasco's Civil Protection agency attributed the deaths to dehydration.</p>    <div class="sdc-article-widget sdc-article-related-stories sdc-article-related-stories--thumbnails" data-component-name="sdc-article-related-stories">
      <div class="sdc-article-related-stories__content">
        <h3 class="sdc-article-related-stories__title">More on Mexico</h3>
    
        <ul class="sdc-article-related-stories__list">
            <li class="sdc-article-related-stories__item">
              <a class="sdc-article-related-stories__link" href="/story/mexico-nine-dead-including-a-child-and-50-injured-after-stage-collapses-at-presidential-campaign-rally-13141614">
                    <div class="sdc-article-related-stories__image-wrap">
                      <amp-img layout="responsive" src="https://e3.365dm.com/24/05/384x216/skynews-mexico-san-pedro-garza-garcia_6563337.jpg?20240523061605" alt="Pic: AP" width="192" height="108" class="sdc-article-related-stories__image"></amp-img>
                    </div>
                <p class="sdc-article-related-stories__link-text">
                  Mexico: Nine dead - including a child - and 50 injured after stage collapses at presidential campaign rally
                </p>
              </a>
            </li>
            <li class="sdc-article-related-stories__item">
              <a class="sdc-article-related-stories__link" href="/story/mexico-fire-breather-fights-off-marauding-mariachis-in-turf-war-over-tips-13141041">
                    <div class="sdc-article-related-stories__image-wrap">
                      <amp-img layout="responsive" src="https://e3.365dm.com/24/05/384x216/skynews-mexico-fire-breather_6562276.jpg?20240521225115" alt="In this image taken from video provided by Jorge Toscano, a flame-swallower, right, and a group of guitar-toting mariachis fight, Sunday, May 19, 2024 in Morelia, Mexico. (Jorge Toscano via AP)" width="192" height="108" class="sdc-article-related-stories__image"></amp-img>
                    </div>
                <p class="sdc-article-related-stories__link-text">
                  Mexico: Fire-breather fights off marauding mariachis in 'turf war over tips'
                </p>
              </a>
            </li>
            <li class="sdc-article-related-stories__item">
              <a class="sdc-article-related-stories__link" href="/story/twin-sisters-who-fought-off-crocodile-attack-to-swim-again-in-13km-race-despite-being-triggered-in-the-water-13136032">
                    <div class="sdc-article-related-stories__image-wrap">
                      <amp-img layout="responsive" src="https://e3.365dm.com/24/05/384x216/skynews-crocodile-attack-twins_6553402.jpg?20240514005235" alt="EMBARGOED TO 0001 TUESDAY MAY 14 Twins Melissa and Georgia Laurie at their home in Sandhurst in Berkshire. Georgia has been included on the King&amp;#39;s first Civilian Gallantry List after she saved her twin sister Melissa from a crocodile attack while they were in Mexico in June 2021. Both women were seriously hurt but survived after treatment, and now Georgia will receive the King&amp;#39;s Gallantry Medal, which acknowledges exemplary acts of bravery. Picture date: Monday May 13, 2024." width="192" height="108" class="sdc-article-related-stories__image"></amp-img>
                    </div>
                <p class="sdc-article-related-stories__link-text">
                  Twin sisters who fought off crocodile attack to swim again in 13km race despite being 'triggered' in the water
                </p>
              </a>
            </li>
        </ul>
    
          <div class="sdc-article-related-stories__tags">
                <div class="sdc-article-tags sdc-article-tags--lozenge" data-align="right">
      <div class="sdc-article-tags__inner">
        <h3 class="sdc-article-tags__title">Related Topics:</h3>
        <ul class="sdc-article-tags__list"><li class="sdc-article-tags__item"><a class="sdc-article-tags__link" href="/topic/mexico-6001">Mexico</a></li><li class="sdc-article-tags__item"><a class="sdc-article-tags__link" href="/topic/climate-change-6161">climate change</a></li></ul>
      </div>
    </div>

          </div>
      </div>
    </div>
<p>A source from the agency said that monkeys have been confirmed dead in three municipalities of the state.</p>     <div class="sdc-article-image sdc-article-image--amp sdc-article-widget">
        <figure class="sdc-article-image__figure">
            <span class="sdc-article-image__wrapper" data-aspect-ratio="16/9">
                        <amp-img src="https://e3.365dm.com/24/05/768x432/skynews-monkey-mexico_6562284.jpg?20240522023549" width="768" height="432" layout="responsive" srcset="https://e3.365dm.com/24/05/384x216/skynews-monkey-mexico_6562284.jpg?20240522023549 380w, https://e3.365dm.com/24/05/768x432/skynews-monkey-mexico_6562284.jpg?20240522023549 760w" alt="A veterinarian feeds a young howler monkey rescued amid extremely high temperatures in Tecolutilla, Tabasco state, Mexico, Tuesday, May 21, 2024. Dozens of howler monkeys were found dead in the Gulf coast state while others were rescued by residents who rushed them to a local veterinarian. (AP Photo/Luis Sanchez)"></amp-img>
            </span>

                <figcaption class="ui-media-caption">
                    <span class="u-hide-visually">Image:</span>
                    <span class="ui-media-caption__caption-text">A vet feeds a young howler monkey rescued amid extremely high temperatures. Pic: AP</span>
                </figcaption>
        </figure>
    </div>
<p>In a forest outside Camalcalco, Tabasco, volunteers collected the corpses of mantled howler monkeys that died from high temperatures, before placing buckets of water and fruit to try to stave off more deaths.</p>        <div class="sdc-article-widget sdc-site-au sdc-site-au--amp site-component-vertical-margin mpu-1">
            <span class="sdc-site-au__label">Advertisement</span>
    
            <amp-ad class="sdc-site-au__item sdc-site-au__mpu-1"
                    width="300"
                    height="250"
                    type="doubleclick"
                    data-slot="20346936/skynews/amp_article"
                    json='{"targeting": {&quot;platform&quot;:&quot;live&quot;,&quot;advert-targeting&quot;:&quot;&#x27;platform&#x27;: &#x27;live&#x27;&quot;,&quot;artId&quot;:&quot;13141048&quot;} }'
                    data-block-on-consent="_till_responded">
            </amp-ad>
        </div>
    <p>The mantled howler monkey is classified as vulnerable on the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) Red List.</p><p>"It is because the heat is so strong. I've been visiting the states for a long time and I have never felt it as much as now," Mexican President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador, who is from Tabasco, said on Monday when asked about the primate deaths.</p><p>"So, yes, we have to care for the animals and yes we are going to do it," he said in his regular news conference.</p>     <div class="sdc-article-image sdc-article-image--amp sdc-article-widget">
        <figure class="sdc-article-image__figure">
            <span class="sdc-article-image__wrapper" data-aspect-ratio="16/9">
                        <amp-img src="https://e3.365dm.com/24/05/768x432/skynews-monkey-mexico_6562286.jpg?20240522023712" width="768" height="432" layout="responsive" srcset="https://e3.365dm.com/24/05/384x216/skynews-monkey-mexico_6562286.jpg?20240522023712 380w, https://e3.365dm.com/24/05/768x432/skynews-monkey-mexico_6562286.jpg?20240522023712 760w" alt="A veterinarian feeds a young howler monkey rescued amid extremely high temperatures in Tecolutilla, Tabasco state, Mexico, Tuesday, May 21, 2024. Dozens of howler monkeys were found dead in the Gulf coast state while others were rescued by residents who rushed them to a local veterinarian. (AP Photo/Luis Sanchez)"></amp-img>
            </span>

                <figcaption class="ui-media-caption">
                    <span class="u-hide-visually">Image:</span>
                    <span class="ui-media-caption__caption-text">Pic: AP</span>
                </figcaption>
        </figure>
    </div>
<p>Later on Monday, <strong><a href="https://news.sky.com/topic/mexico-6001" target="_blank">Mexico's</a></strong> environment ministry said in a statement that it was coordinating efforts to address the monkeys' deaths, which it attributed to several possible reasons, including "heat stroke, dehydration, malnutrition or the spraying of crops with toxic agrochemicals."</p><p><strong>Read more:</strong><br /><a href="https://news.sky.com/story/mexico-fire-breather-fights-off-marauding-mariachis-in-turf-war-over-tips-13141041" target="_blank"><strong>Fire-breather fights off marauding mariachis in 'turf war'</strong></a><br /><strong><a href="https://news.sky.com/story/images-show-inside-of-singapore-airlines-plane-after-one-killed-in-turbulence-13140773">Images show damage inside plane after one killed</a><br /><a href="https://news.sky.com/story/singapore-airlines-is-flight-turbulence-getting-worse-and-what-types-are-there-13140799">Turbulence is getting worse - here's the main reason why</a></strong></p><p>Mexico's health ministry reported a preliminary count of 26 people who have died from heat-related causes between the start of Mexico's heat season on 17 March and 11 May.</p><p>By 9 May at least nine cities in Mexico had set temperature records, with Ciudad Victoria, in the border state of Tamaulipas, clocking a broiling 47C.</p><p>With sub-average rainfall across almost the entire country so far this year, lakes and reservoirs are drying up, water supplies are running out and authorities have had to truck in water for everything from hospitals to fire-fighting teams.</p>     <div class="sdc-article-image sdc-article-image--amp sdc-article-widget">
        <figure class="sdc-article-image__figure">
            <span class="sdc-article-image__wrapper" data-aspect-ratio="16/9">
                        <amp-img src="https://e3.365dm.com/24/05/768x432/skynews-monkey-mexico_6562285.jpg?20240522023624" width="768" height="432" layout="responsive" srcset="https://e3.365dm.com/24/05/384x216/skynews-monkey-mexico_6562285.jpg?20240522023624 380w, https://e3.365dm.com/24/05/768x432/skynews-monkey-mexico_6562285.jpg?20240522023624 760w" alt="Howler monkeys sit in a cage at a veterinarian clinic after they were rescued amid extremely high temperatures in Tecolutilla, Tabasco state, Mexico, Tuesday, May 21, 2024. Dozens of howler monkeys were found dead in the Gulf coast state while others were rescued by residents who rushed them to a local veterinarian. (AP Photo/Luis Sanchez)"></amp-img>
            </span>

                <figcaption class="ui-media-caption">
                    <span class="u-hide-visually">Image:</span>
                    <span class="ui-media-caption__caption-text">Pic: AP</span>
                </figcaption>
        </figure>
    </div>
<p>Low water levels at hydroelectric plants have contributed to power blackouts in some parts of the country.</p><p>Wildlife biologist Gilberto Pozo counted about 83 of the animals dead or dying on the ground under trees.</p><p>"This is a sentinel species," Mr Pozo said, referring to the canary-in-a-coal mine effect where one species can say a lot about an ecosystem.</p><p>"It is telling us something about what is happening with climate change."</p>
        </div>

                <div class="sdc-article-widget sdc-site-outbrain sdc-site-outbrain--amp sdc-site-outbrain--AMP_1">
                    <amp-embed width="100" height="100" type="outbrain" layout="responsive" data-widgetIds="AMP_1" data-htmlURL="" data-ampURL="https://news.sky.com/story/amp/howler-monkeys-drop-dead-from-the-trees-as-heatwave-rages-in-mexico-13141048" data-block-on-consent>
                        <div overflow tabindex=0 role=button aria-label="Outbrain Recommendations">Outbrain</div>
                    </amp-embed>
                </div>
    
    </main>
</div>
